Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Field Ecology at the University of Virginia's Blandy Experimental Farm
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of Virginia that will provide research training for 10 students, for 11 weeks during the summers of 2012- 2016. The program focuses on field biology, encompassing the application of field research, experimental design, data analysis, and synthesis to the main research areas of plant-insect interactions, pollination biology, ecosystem ecology, conservation, invasive species, aquatic ecology, and applied insect ecology. The students have a choice of mentors from a pool of about 7 resident and visiting faculty at Blandy Experimental Farm. In addition to carrying out research projects, students are required to participate in weekly seminars given by visiting scholars as well various workshops, such as the ethical conduct of research, getting into and surviving graduate school, and how to communicate scientific research effectively. Students are provided tours of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History and take advantage of numerous biological and cultural opportunities in Northern Virginia. Blandy Experimental Farm is an ecological field station (not a farm) at the northern edge of the Shenandoah Valley. It is rural in character, but not isolated: it lies within 10 miles of the Shenandoah River, the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the Appalachian Trail, and only 60 miles from Washington, DC. REU students have access to a new laboratory building, a greenhouse and screenhouse, and a variety of habitat types for field research. Recruitment of students is carried out through campus visits, poster mailings, and online advertising. Students are chosen based on their prior academic performance, recommendations, and interests. Student outcomes are evaluated throughout their attendance in the program. The program will be evaluated through several approaches including the use of an REU common assessment tool. Post-program follow-up surveys of students gauge long-term impacts on their interests in scientific research and science education outreach, academic performance, and career advancement. Information is available at www.virginia.edu/blandy/ReuWebPage/HomePage.php or by contacting the PI (Dr. Haynes at haynes@virginia.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. McKenna at mmckenna@howard.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates Field Ecology program at the University of Virginia’s Blandy Experimental Farm guided a diverse body of undergraduate students through a comprehensive program designed to teach students how to answer important questions in environmental biology using the tools of the scientific method. By carrying out innovative research under the guidance of research mentors, the students gained first-hand experience in designing experiments, data collection, data analysis, and written and oral communication of results to other scientists and the general public. The students gained additional training by attending professional-development workshops on a variety of topics such as how to store and share digital data, how to effectively communicate scientific concepts and research findings to young children, and how to gain admission to and succeed in graduate school. To increase the positive impact of the program on society, the program trained many members of groups that are underrepresented in science, including women and minorities, and students enrolled in colleges or universities that do not have formal research programs. Demonstrating the success of this program, several participants publish the results of their research projects in scientific journals and large numbers enrolled in graduate school programs in biology, ecology, or related fields. Nearly all of the participants agreed or strongly agreed their research experience prepared them for both graduate school and a job, indicating this program will likely have long-lasting socioeconomic benefits.
